localized.title: How to create an AR application with OpenCV, ESP32, and FreeRTOS
localized.description:
In this tutorial, we'll show you how to create an augmented reality application using a webcam, OpenCV, ESP32, and FreeRTOS. We're going to use the webcam to capture video, OpenCV to process video and detect fingers, ESP32 to control the lights, and FreeRTOS to manage the system. We will also use a temperature sensor to retrieve temperature and pressure values.

First, we're going to start with setting up the hardware. We are going to connect the webcam to the ESP32 and start it up. Next, we're going to connect the temperature sensor to the ESP32 and set it up to measure temperature and pressure.

Then we are going to move on to the software part. We are going to use OpenCV to process video captured by the webcam and to detect fingers in the video stream. We're going to use the ESP32 to control the lights and adjust their brightness and color based on finger detection. We are also going to use FreeRTOS to manage the system and ensure that everything is working properly.

Once we've set up the system, we'll test it and show you how it works. We will use the webcam to capture video, the temperature sensor to retrieve temperature and pressure values, OpenCV to process video and detect hands, and the ESP32 to control the lights.

localized.title: Recognition of presidents' faces with an AI based on convolutional neural networks
localized.description:
In this video, we explore the creation of artificial intelligence that can recognize presidents' faces using deep learning and convolutional neural networks. We start by explaining the different steps of the process, from collecting data to creating a user-friendly web application with Streamlit.

First, we approach data collection by bringing together a vast set of images of different presidents from a variety of sources. We also discuss the challenges of manually tagging images to train our facial recognition model.

Next, we explore data augmentation techniques to diversify our training set. Increasing data involves transformations such as rotating, cropping, and scaling images to improve the generalizability of our model.

We then move on to creating and training our convolutional neural network model. We explain the different layers of the model, such as the convolution, pooling, and fully connected layers, and their role in learning the characteristics of presidential faces.

Once the model is trained, we move on to creating an interactive web application using Streamlit. This application will allow users to upload an image containing the face of a president and instantly get a prediction of his identity thanks to our face recognition model.

By following this video, you will gain a thorough understanding of the process of creating a facial recognition AI based on convolutional neural networks. You will be able to replicate these steps for other image recognition applications.

localized.title: How to detect faces, eyes, and smiles in an image with Python and OpenCV
localized.description:
In this video, we'll learn how to use Python and OpenCV to automatically detect faces, eyes, and smiles in an image. We are going to use Viola-Jones' Haar Cascade feature detection method, which is a very effective technique for detecting objects in images. We'll start by explaining how this technique works, and then we'll see how to use it to detect faces, eyes, and smiles in an image. We'll also discuss important parameters like the scaleFactor and minNeighbors that affect detection accuracy. Finally, we will see how to visualize the detection results in an image, and how to save these results for later use.

During the video, we'll go through the following steps:

Importing the OpenCV library into Python
Download Haar Cascade files for face, eye, and smile detection
Loading an image from a file or URL
Converting the image to greyscale to improve detection
Face, eye, and smile detection with the Haar Cascade method
Changing the value of the scaleFactor and minNeighbors parameters to improve detection accuracy
Visualization of detection results in an image
Save detection results to an image file
At the end of the video, you'll be able to automatically detect faces, eyes, and smiles in an image using Python and OpenCV. This skill can be applied to numerous image analysis projects, such as security monitoring, facial recognition, feeling analysis, and more.

localized.title: What do you need to know before starting computer vision?
localized.description:
This video talks in a fairly general way about the concepts you need to know before starting computer vision. The aim is to identify the pillars of this discipline. We discuss the notions of images and videos, then the different types of cameras and their specificities. Then it is important to know the different computing powers such as CPUs, GPUs and TPU as well as the different microcontrollers used, Nvidia jetson nano, Google Coral, Raspberry pi, etc... 
Know which frameworks (OpenCV, YOLO,..) are used and which artificial intelligence technologies such as neural networks (CNN,...) and Machine Learning algorithms.

#computervision #artificialintelligence #maths #algorithms #ml
